comments:
3.3 M2

- I upgraded from 3.2 to 3.3 M3
- my workspace uses Links folders pointing to EMF and GEF
- the one for EMF pointed a base EMF install that was missing SDO stuff
- this caused the plugin for a custom filesystem to fail
- this caused the reading of the .project files for all projects using that filesystem to fail, however the failure mode was not obvious: it gave a "SAXParseException: Premature end of file" for each project, suggesting that the file had been corrupted though the files were in fact fine
- there was no log entry for the filesystem extension failure (or if it was, it was lost in the noise of all the other plugin failure and SAXException log entries)

Suggestions:
- if the filesystem extension can't be loaded, give a clear log entry for that failure and skip trying to read projects with that filesystem
- provide more details in the SAXException, e.g. exactly which project was affected

Sample log entry.
Notice:
1. no details about which project was affected
2. there are two subentries that look identical

The SAXExceptions were followed by the following entry, which also suggests the .project files were corrupt.  Though this entry lists the project ids, it would still be useful to provide that in the SAXException entries.

!ENTRY org.eclipse.core.resources 4 567 2006-09-25 11:02:00.234
!MESSAGE Workspace restored, but some problems occurred.
!SUBENTRY 1 org.eclipse.core.resources 4 567 2006-09-25 11:02:00.234
!MESSAGE Failed to read the project description file (.project) for 'some.project'.  The file has been changed on disk, and it now contains invalid information.  The project will not function properly until the description file is restored to a valid state.

(with 1 subentry for each project affected)

Easy to reproduce by creating a project in a non-local filesystem, and then removing the plugin that defines that file system.  We are silently replacing missing file systems with a dummy file system that does not fail, but will return an empty stream when you ask for the file contents.  This is clearly not the right failure mode. I will work on improving the failure case so that the cause of the failure is more clear to the end-user.

I fixed up the EMF dependency, cleaned out the config and relaunched. It came up without any errors. I was able to reopen the projects, but now they have only the .project file (despite the other files being there on disk). 

Refresh brings the files back in, but I wouldn't expect to have to do this. 
I guess it lost some state when I shut down the "broken" session with the projects closed.

Ok, the error message is now (where 'a' is the name of the project, and 'memory' is the file system scheme):

!ENTRY org.eclipse.core.resources 4 567 2006-09-25 16:05:07.093
!MESSAGE Workspace restored, but some problems occurred.
!SUBENTRY 1 org.eclipse.core.resources 4 567 2006-09-25 16:05:07.093
!MESSAGE Could not read metadata for 'a'.
!STACK 1
org.eclipse.core.runtime.CoreException: No file system is defined for scheme: memory
	at org.eclipse.core.internal.filesystem.Policy.error(Policy.java:56)

Fix released. Although the code path is no longer hit in this case, I have also changed the project description parsing code to include the name of the project when there are parsing failures (in cases where the project name is known).

traces.message: No file system is defined for scheme: memory
